roles_in_work.title: Life forms, animals and animal oddities

results.name: Queensland University. Department of Human Movement
Tony Agapitos

roles_in_work.title: [Tony Agapitos: Preparations for Miss Greek Charity Quest]
[Tony Agapitos: Arrival of the Greek Ship "Patris" at Victoria Dock 1]
[Tony Agapitos: Celebration of National Day of the Greek Community]
[Tony Agapitos: Easter celebrations at Green Hill]
[Tony Agapitos: First Greek Community Dance at Exhibition Centre 1961]
[Tony Agapitos: Greek Boy Scouts and Girl Guides supporting Bishop at Festival Hall]

results.biography:
Tony Agapitos was a Greek immigrant and filmmaker who documented life in Melbourne's Greek community from the 1950s to the 70s. He focused on significant political, social and religious events, including the arrival of Greek ships at Victoria docks, celebrations and dances, protest marches, political meetings and religious occasions. Mr Agapitos' material comprises approximately three hours of footage and was shot on 16mm and 35mm film, which is preserved in our collection.

Born in Egypt to Greek parents, Tony gained valuable qualifications in filmmaking during his lifetime. He was involved in cinematography, specialising in documentary and news films, and also worked as a projectionist and technical director.

After arriving in Australia in the late 1940s, he was employed from 1950-1953 as an instrument engineer with S.L.I. Lucas Australia. From 1953–1958 he was with Herschell’s Film Studio where he was involved in film maintenance and production. This included directing, editing, camera work and sound recording. Tony was active in the production of films for D24 Masonic Hospital and he also produced his own films. From 1958 he was at the State Film Centre, employed as a Biograph Projectionist travelling all around Victoria.

Some of Tony’s personal footage was shown in a documentary about the history of Station and Princes Piers in Port Melbourne, as part of a restoration celebration in 2012. Princes Pier in particular played a key role in Australia’s wartime and multicultural history as the first landing in Australia for thousands of post war migrants. Tony’s films capture the pathos of the new arrivals; they are beautiful and emotionally powerful evocations of the experience.

Fragments of Tony’s work have also been used by participants in our Digital Storytelling workshops, bringing strong narrative drive to the participant’s personal stories, enabling them to communicate the complex emotional landscape of arrival in a strange country.

results.name: Warren Burt
results.biography:
Beginning in 1973 in San Diego, I began extending my work in
generating sound with electronic algorithmic processes into the visual realm. In San Diego, a Serge analog sound synthesizer was used in conjunction with a Beck video encoder box to produce works such as
"Dying Song," which explored slowly changing basic shapes derived from changing aspects of the horizontal and vertical video sync frequencies.

On moving to Melbourne in 1975, I began working with Richard
Monkhouse's EMS Spectre Video synthesizer. This allowed
treatment of camera made video (as in "Nighthawk Part 3 - Bittern"
(1976)), and also generation of abstract imagery. ("Nocturnals
(1977)). Again, these works were generated by algorithmic
processes, which I interacted with in real time to produce a final
product.

The Spectre and the Rutt-Etra Video Synthesizers were used in
1978-79 to make "Moods", a 2 hour set of 15 works. Many different
techniques were used in this work, from collage ("for Ives and Jobim")
to using analog sound synthesis techniques to generate images ("after
Monk") to using the Rutt-Etra to distort performers faces in real time, and having the performers use these distortions as a score for vocal performance. ("3 Views").

In 1986 at International Synergy Institute in Los Angeles, I used a
Fairlight Video Synthesizer to make "Meditations", a 2 hour set of 24
five minute pieces. Again, the method used in making these was to set
up an automated process, and then interact with it in real time, making abstract images that I felt I could move with, and that created an environment I wanted to live in. Video feedback processes were also used here, but I tried to avoid the cliches of video feedback.
("Meditation 10" and "Meditation 13").

From 1992-1996, I worked with Jim Binkley's real-time computer
graphics animation program PIP, which put out the now obsolete
EGA graphics. PIP was an offshoot of Binkley's algorithmic RAVEL
music language, and had many interesting process generation features
in it, such as Iterated Function Systems routines, which generated
chaos graphics. In 1996, I performed "2 Solo Interactions" with this
piece- a live interaction with the computer for voice and movement,
where my movements controlled both the video and sound produced,
at the Canberra School of Art and the Australian Centre for the Arts
and Technology.

In all this work, my aesthetic has been one of setting up a process and then learning/devising ways to interact with that process. The aim of my work has been primarily exploratory, rather than primarily
narrative or expressive. I am hopefully using this work to find out
what I don't know, and to change myself, rather than using it to simply express what I already know. In some of the works, my aim was for a common process to generate both image and sound. In other
works, parallel processes, were used. And in some works, sound and
image were only related by happening at the same time. The
exploration of all sorts of relationships between sound, image and language has been very important for me. I stand for diversity, and not the following of one style or another.


VIDEO and FILM works
"A Guided Tour to the Caves of Uranus" (1974)

color NTSC U-matic video and sound synthesis (23 mins)
performed: University of California, San Diego, 1975; Immaculate Heart College, Los Angeles 1975; Clifton Hill Community Music Centre, Melbourne, 1976.
Made with Serge Analog Synth, Beck Video Encoder at Center for Music Experiment, University of California, San Diego.
Very slowly changing video - a live improvisation of both sound and image - the essence of what it meant to be a Young California Minimal Artist (YCMA).

"Very Smart Microbes" (1975)

Color NTSC U-matic video and sound synthesis (34 mins)
performed: University of California, San Diego 1975, Clifton Hill Community Music Centre, Melbourne 1976
Made with: Serge Analog Synth, Beck Video Encoder, at Centre for Music Experiment, University of California, San Diego
In three sections, this work deals with surfing electronic processes and observing the results, which are slowly changing and mesmeric.

"Fatty Acid: The School of Cage" (1975)

B+W NTSC U-matic documentary video tape (45 mins) in collaboration with Ronald Al Robboy and David Dunn
performed: University of California, San Diego, 1975;
documents from tape published Ear Magazine, New York, 1977.
Made with: B+W video camera, U-Matic recorder at Center for Music Experiment, University of California, San Diego. Camera work on tape by Ed Emshwiller.
Fatty Acid was a performance art group that specialized in incompetent performance and musicology. This is a documentation of our expose of the Rockefeller led machinations in the US avant-garde music scene in the 1930s and their horrifying consequences in the 1950s. Made of course, with funding from the Rockefeller Foundation.

"Recital" (1975)

B+W NTSC U-Matic video performance - voice and piano accordion (15 mins)
in collaboration with Jennifer Kotter, camera;
performed: 1987, Australian Centre for Contemporary Art, Melbourne, WB
Made with: B+W camera, 3/4 inch deck, at Center for Music Experiment, University of California, San Diego
A score exists in my archives. As I remember, I was performing a bunch of political songs with ukelele and doing other performance art type gestures. Not a major work, but fun, as I remember.

"Nighthawk" (1972-76)

videotape, 4 channel tape, slides, and live performer - solo opera (3 1/2 hours)
pt. 1 - live reader and 2 slide projectors;
pt. 2 - 4 channel tape and 1 slide projector;
pt. 3 - color videotape (PAL U-Matic) and stereo soundtrack. (80 minutes)
performed: University of California, San Diego 1975 (pt. 1 - staging by Ned Sublette); University of California, Santa Cruz 1974 (pt. 1 - staging by William Brooks); La Trobe Uni. Music Rostrum Festival 1976; Sydney Opera House (Bill Fontana's Sunday afternoon series) 1976; Adelaide University; San Diego State University; University of Illinois, Urbana; Oberlin Conservatorium; Experimental Intermedia Foundation, NYC; University of New Mexico, Albuquerque; State Uni. of NY, Albany; California Institute of the Arts, Los Angeles; 1977; La Trobe Uni.(part 3) 1978, (part 2) 1981;
Part 1 Published By Lingua Press, Iowa City, 1976
Video portion made with: B+W portapak, super-8 film for animation of headlines, EMS Spectre Synthesizer, Serge Analog Synthesizer, John Roy Daisy system (digital control voltage generator), 2-deck video delay system, video switcher.
Video portion made at La Trobe University Studios.
An 80 minute train journey, with music - and video-concrete overlays, all heavily colourized. As uncompromising a minimalist and cut-up language statement as you're likely to find anywhere.

"Uncovering Resonances" (1976)

B+W PAL video- voices, cassettes and environment (35 mins) with Ron Nagorcka and Dan Robinson, Rye Ocean Beach, 1976;
performed: La Trobe Uni 1978
Made with 1/2 inch B+W portapak, at Rye Ocean Beach.
Camera by Dan Robinson.
A video documentation of a Plastic Platypus performance by Ron Nagorcka and Warren Burt doing Tibetan Chant on a windswept beach and using cassette recorders to make noisebands out of it.

"Two Nocturnals- A-3:5:9 and B-4:6:7" (1977)

color PAL video and sound synthesis tapes (37mins & 38mins)
performed: Melbourne, 1977; La Trobe Uni, 1978; Sydney, 1979; New Music America Festival, Hartford, 1984.
Made with EMS Spectre Video Synthesizer, at La Trobe University Electronic Music Studios.
Gently changing images. Mostly jewel like flickering patterns on a black background. Combining the analog soft-edged images of the California work with the more hard-edge imagery made by the digital synthesis methods of the Spectre.

"Shadowdrum" (1977)

color PAL modified live video and timpani (20 mins) collaboration with John McCaughey,
tape performed: La Trobe Uni. 1978
Made with B+W camera, Serge Analog Synthesizer, EMS Spectre Video Synthesizer at La Trobe University Electronic Music Studios.
The camera signal is processed thru the analog sound synthesizers filters, etc. before being routed into the Spectre for colourizing. A very abstract image which then moves in sync with the timpani being played. The in-joke here was that John McCaughey's nickname at the time was "The Shadow", from his ability to suddenly appear behind someone as if he had been invisible. So in this tape, we made him visually invisible, but sonically still audible.

"Two Documentaries on Bill Fontana's Work" (1978)

B+W PAL video tape (20 mins each)
performed: National Gallery, Melb. 1978
Made with B+W video deck, (dubbed to 3/4 inch PAL U-Matic) at Gundagai, NSW, and on the Frankston Railway Line, Melbourne.
They were shown at the NGV in conjunction with a big sound sculpture show of Bill Fontana's in 1978. I remember liking the Frankston line video a lot, which, after showing Bill and his assistants setting up microphones and radio transmitters along the railway line, consisted of about 15 minutes of just shooting the inside of a train carriage while it was moving.

"Danger Dance" (1978)

PAL U-matic color video (6 minutes) collaboration with Eva Karczag.
Tape performed Clifton Hill Community Music Centre, 1978, 1979, and sometime in Sydney.
Made with Super 8 film, slowed down and transferred to video. Sound made with primitive Lexicon digital rate changer, at La Trobe University Electronic Music Studios.
Just a slowed down super 8 film that is shot with a camera and transferred to video, but the texture of the film colours and the video transfer are interesting, as is the piece itself, a slow-motion long walk off a short pier.

"Silver (Piano Dance)" (1978)

color PAL video of dance with off-camera piano (35 mins)
collaboration with Eva Karczag, dance;
tape performed: Watters Gallery, Sydney, 1978; Alexander Mackie School of Art, Sydney, 1987;
live performance: Dartington College of Arts, England, 1978;
piano solo version (5 mins), Paris Autumn Festival, 1983
Made with Colour camera, PAL U-Matic recorder at La Trobe University Electronic Music Studios.
A structuralist dance, with structuralist music accompaniment. Slow and dreamy, like much we did back then. And VERY repetitious.

"Salt 81:80:63" (1978)

color PAL modified live video and synthesized sound (6 mins)
performed: La Trobe Uni 1979
Made with Sound transducer on a metal plate. Camera on metal plate processed by EMS Spectre Video Synthesizer at La Trobe University Electronic Music Studios.
A realization of Alvin Lucier's "Queen of the South". It pulses, it grows, it throbs. In time with the sound.

"Intercut" and "Slow Moving in the Big City" (1979-80)

super 8 color sound films (20 mins and 10 mins) dance films made with Eva Karczag and soundtracks made in collaboration with Ronald Al Robboy;
performed: New York, Melbourne, 1980
Made with Super 8 film technology at an abandoned warehouse in San Diego, dance studios and on the streets in Manhattan.
Structuralist dance-film experiments made by Eva Karczag with me. I remember best Intercut, with its set of an empty warehouse and disappearing dancer, with changing distances on an otherwise still camera.

"Moods" (1978-79)

color PAL synthetic video and sound (2 hours) performed: Kitchen, NYC; Clifton Hill Community Music Centre; Adelaide Uni, 1980; Modern Image Makers Assn. screenings, Melbourne, 1986
Made with Hearn EAB Videolab, Serge Analog Synth, EMS Spectre Video Synth at WRPI, Troy, NY, video research studios; La Trobe University Electronic Music Studios; Adelaide University Electronic Music Studio, Paddington Video Access Centre studio with help from S. Jones.
My major video work from the 1970s. (Article on this in Cantrill's Film Notes)

"Der Yiddisher Cowboy - A Film in English" (1974-79)

super 8 color sound film (2 hours 10 mins) in collaboration with Ronald Al Robboy.
performed: Clifton Hill Community Music Centre, 1980; Melbourne State College; Video Plus Festival, Sydney, 1981; University of California, San Diego, 1982; University of Iowa, Iowa City, 1984.
Made with Super 8 film technology on the mean streets of San Diego, and in La Mesa and Lakeside, California.
Undoubtedly one of the most important contributions to Yiddish culture and film scholarship ever made. A culmination of a decade of collaboration and work on film culture, incompetance, politics, music and spirituality between RAR and WAB. Robboy has, in the 20 years since the film was made, continued the work, and uncovered a wealth of new material. A sequel waits anxiously, or maybe, patiently, to be made. (Article on this in Cantrill's Film Notes)

"If Structure is an Empty Glass" (1978-80)

super-8 color sound film (90 mins)
performed: Clifton Hill Community Music Centre, 1980
Made with Super 8 film technology at La Trobe University Electronic Music Studios, various environments in Australia, New York, etc.
An 80 minute structuralist Super-8 film which met with almost total incomprehension in its first (and only) full length showing. I'd like to revive this someday and see if a second showing would be a bit kinder to it. But maybe this time, I won't waste my time by showing it to cinema-studies and art students!

"Requiem" (1980)

super-8 color sound film (10 mins) with David Dunn, violin;
performed: Clifton Hill Community Music Centre, 1980
Made with Radio microphone technology, Super-8 film technology at various locations around Waterford, NY.
A memorial to my grandfather. David Dunn plays a violin melody in various environments that were meaningful to him.

"Tidepools" (1980)

super-8 color sound film (10 mins) with Ronald All Robboy, speaking voice and live electronics;
performed: Clifton Hill Community Music Centre, 1980
Made with Super-8 film technology at Point Loma tidepools, San Diego, California.
Ron Robboy narrates what he sees at the San Diego tidepools. This became the prototype for one of the sections of "Nature" which was made at the Sorrento, Vic. tidepools with Dr. Jane Calder, marine biologist.

"Computer Dance Video" (1980-81)

color PAL treated synthetic video and electronic sounds (9 mins)
collaboration with Eva Karczag, dance and Tom DeWitt, video;
performed: La Trobe Uni 1981
Made with George Kindler's Electronic Pantograph system, Hearn EAB videolab, EMS Spectre Video Synth, at.
WRPI, Troy NY video synthesis lab, Joel Chadabe's private electronic music studio, Albany, NY; La Trobe University Electronic Music Studios.
Eva moves to computer music made from transcriptions of the numerology of her name. Parts of her body are picked up by an early colorizer - video memory unit and remembered. The video was then transferred to PAL and colourized at the La Trobe Uni. studio.

"Melbourne City Square Video Show" (1981)

live media performance (1 hour) in collaboration with Chris Mann, Ron Nagorcka, Chris Wyatt, Robert Randall, Frank Bendinelli, David Chesworth, Philip Brophy, Gary Willis and Eva Schramm, for Moomba, Melbourne, 1981; super 8 color sound film of "Snodger in the Square" section-collaboration between Burt, Mann and Wyatt.
film shown at La Trobe Uni 1981
Made with EMS Spectre Video Synth live on a giant outdoor TV screen at Melbourne City Square.
Documentation super-8 film made with super-8 film technology.
A documentation of a live big public video event. The film later had an independent life accompanying a performance by Chris Mann. (Article on this event in Cantrill's Film Notes)

"In Memoriam Bill Evans" (1982)

color PAL synthetic videotape with electronic soundtrack (25 mins)
performed: RMIT, Melbourne; Clifton Hill Community Music Centre, 1982
Made with Oscilloscope, Camera, Serge Analog Synth, EMS Spectre Video Synth, at La Trobe University Electronic Music Studios.
Sound synth makes patterns on oscilloscope. Camera picks up oscilloscope. Camera is processed by analog sound synth before being colourized by EMS Video synth. Sound is a mix of 5 cassettes of fragments of Bill Evans' piano playing.

"Variations on a Summer's Evening" (1982)

color PAL synthetic video and sound (23 mins)
performed: State Film Centre, Melbourne 1982
Made with EMS spectre video synth, Serge analog synth, in live performance at State Film Centre, Melbourne
A live performance for a very chaotic event at the State Film Centre. I remember very little about it, except that the event left a very bad taste in my mouth.

"Nature" (1981-83)

super-8 color sound film (90 mins)
performed: Clifton Hill Community Music Centre, 1983; Linden Gallery, St. Kilda, 1987; PICA, Perth, 1988
Made with Super-8 film technology in various environments around Melbourne.
My major super 8 film work of the 1980s. As well, my major response to Thoreau's "Journal". (Article about this in Cantrill's Film Notes)

"Meditations" (1986)

Color NTSC Video and Sound Synthesis (2 hours)
performed: International Synergy, Los Angeles; EZTV, Los Angeles; Sydney International Video Festival, 1986; Melbourne Film Festival; American Film Institute National Video Show, Los Angeles, 1986; broadcast Group W Cable, USA, 1986; Queensland University; Griffith University, Queensland College of Art; Perth Institute of Contemporary Art, Perth, 1988.
Made with Fairlight CVI, Serge Analog Synth, Casio CZ101 synth at International Synergy Studios, Los Angeles.
My major video work from the 1980s. Deals a lot with chaotic processes as a generator for video synthesis. Also my last big fling with musical minimalism of the pulse and tonality variety.

"The Duck Tapes - Chapter 9 - The Flesh of this Fowl" (1986)

color NTSC video tape (1hour)
dance/performance art tape made in colloboration with choreographer Lou Blankenburg for broadcast on "Dancings", Iowa City Public TV, 1986
Made with broadcast video portable cameras on the banks of the Iowa River, and in the studios of Iowa City Public TV.
Be silly. Be very silly.

"String Trio No. 2" (1981-86)

color PAL video tape (12 mins)
performers: Angela Dillon (now Anja Tait), violin, viola, cello; Stephen Goddard, video mix; Warren Burt, sound mix.
Tape performed: Modern Image Makers Assn. Touring Exhibition, Australia, 1987; Australian Centre for Contemporary Art, Melbourne; Alexander Mackie College of Art, Sydney; La Trobe University, Melbourne; 1987; Queensland University; Griffith University; Bellas Gallery, Brisbane; Queensland College of Art; Perth Institute of Contemporary Art, Perth, 1988.
Made with broadcast quality video cameras and mixing technology at Armstrong Reserve, Seaford, Vic.; Rusden State College Video Studio.
Three parts, one performer. Environmental sounds trigger off what the performer plays, how the video mixer mixes image, how the sound mixer mixes sound. (Article about this in Cantrill's Film Notes)

"Three Short 3DIS Dances" (1988)

collaboration with Shona Innes, using 3DIS system, for HSV7 TV program "Beyond 2000", 1988.
Made with 3DIS video-to-MIDI system, broadcast TV technology at HSV7 studios, Melbourne.
Shown all around the world. My Aunts and Uncles were then convinced that what I was doing had some sort of legitimacy.

"anyway you can always put language down to experience" (1989)

collaboration with Chris Mann. reading voice, live computer, live electronic voice processings, video and sculpture.
Performed at Ars Electronica, Linz, Austria, Sept. 89; Telecommunications and Art, V2 Gallery, s'Hertogenbosch, Holland, Sept. 89; Monash University, March 90; Next Wave Festival, Melbourne, May 90;
Broadcast in excerpt: Jan 90 ABC-FM; March 8 90, ABC FM; complete: May 89 ABC-FM; April 89 3MBS-FM, Melbourne.
excerpt released on CD from V2, 1990 (38 mins)
Video component: I don't remember what the video component of this piece was! Except that it was viewed thru a screen of plastic lenses. It might have been just a TV tuned to no channel. I honestly can't remember. This was mainly a sound piece performed in a set, and the set involved some sort of video distorted by the screen of lenses. The video component was Chris's part, I think. I just remember this as mainly a sound piece.

"A Random Walk Around Melbourne" (1989)

super 8 film and live electronics.
Performed at Modern Image Makers Assn. Show, Melbourne, Nov. 89; Linden Gallery, Apr. 1990 (14 mins)
Made with Random Number Chart, Melbourne Public Transport Map; Super 8 film technology, FM radio, Yamaha sound effects unit, all over Melbourne.
Live performance at Linden Gallery.
The live performance involved me doing fast scans of the AM radio spectrum thru an effects unit that made all signals, whether faint or loud, of equal volume. I changed channels randomly every time the scene changed on the film. A random scan of the radio sound spectrum in real time to accompany a film of random places around Melbourne.

"There is Nothing More Provocative Than Minding Your Own Business" (1989)

2 super 8 films, live computer system and tape (15'38")
Made with Super-8 film technology in Melbourne somewhere.
I think this piece was never shown. I don't know why. I haven't looked at the films since it was made and remember almost nothing about it.

"38:37 - A Machine for Making Sense" (1990)

PAL 3/4 U-matic Colour Videotape. Video by Warren Burt, Sound by Chris Mann.
Videotape version exhibited Ivan Dougherty Gallery, Sydney, Oct. 90 as part of Sydney Video Festival.
Live version for video projection, reader and synthesizer player/page turner performed Dec. 90, Malthouse Theatre, Melbourne as part of Experimenta'90 (40 mins)
Made with Serge Analog Synth, Fairlight CVI, EMS Spectre Video Synth at Randelli Studio, South Yarra. The EMS Spectre Video Synth in their studio is the one formerly owned by La Trobe University. Edited at Rusden State College Video Studio.

"Six Soundtracks in Search of a Visual (An Assemblage)" (1990)

live computer and electronics, performed simultaneously with video portion of "38:37."
performed: Griffith University, Brisbane, Aug. 90 (40 mins)
Using the same video above, I performed an experiment, doing a live mixing collage to it, without the Chris Mann voice track.

'THE" Movie' (1990)

black and white silent super 8 film.
Collaboration with Phil Larsen and Ed Harkins ("The").
Shown at White Gloves Film Festival, Oct 90 Melbourne (3 mins)
Made with Super-8 film technology in Exhibition Gardens, Carlton, Melbourne.
My contribution to the 1990 White Gloves Film Festival, made with two composer/perfomer friends from San Diego. Making a silent film of two virtuosic vocalists.

"A Walk Around My Living Room with Cageian Celebration and Moose" (1983-91)

super-8 film, spotlight, Bullwinkle the Moose icons and live moose (small synthesizer in a Bullwinkle radio)
performers: W. Burt, moose; Ernie Althoff, spotlight;
Modern Image Makers Assn. series, Linden Gallery, St. Kilda. Apr. 91 (9 mins)
Made with Super-8 film technology, Serge Analog Synth, Bullwinkle synthesizer in Carlton, Vic. 1983 and St. Kilda, 1991
A complex synthesizer patch plays while the Bullwinkle synthesizer sings its chaotic feedback song. The camera wanders around the living room with the synth playing while the live performer plays on the Bullwinkle synth.

"Tram Piece" (1991)

2 superimposed super 8 films and 2 samplers with samples of tram sounds.
Collaboration with Chris Knowles.
performed: Modern Image Makers Assn. series, Linden Gallery, St. Kilda, Apr. 91 (14 mins)
Made with Super-8 film technology, 2 samplers, in Warren Burt and Chris Knowles studios, St. Kilda. Also on the Melbourne tram system and in live performance at the Linden Gallery.
I remember this improvisation as being a lot of fun. Too bad no-one made a video of the event. C'est la vie.

"Slogans and Abstracts" (1992)

computer animation and music videotape or l live computer with EGA colour monitor and EMU Proteus synthesizer. (26 mins)
Made with IBM 286 laptop computer, PIP computer animation program, EMU Proteus synthesizer at Composers studio, St. Kilda. Converted to video at ACGC, CITRI, RMIT, 1994.
PIP was a wonderful DOS program that bounced PCX paint clippings around the computer screen. I think with this piece I took it about as far as I could, but who knows, maybe I'll do something else with it someday.

"Continuously Retitled" (1992)

for video projection, live computer animation, videotape, live electronics and Lightning MIDI controller. Collaboration with Csaba Szamosy and Chris Mann.
Performed at Experimenta, Melbourne, 28 November 1992. (20 mins)
Made with Computer graphics component made by Csaba Szamosy with Amiga computer in live performance at Theatreworks, St. Kilda.
The computer graphics were a live animation of shots of Chris Mann's face. We also had a videotape playing of Chris's hands while he read. The monitor with the face animations was on top of the monitor with the video of Chris's hands. So we had an electronic simulacrum of Chris, while he read facing the wall, with his hands held steady behind his back.

"Processor" (1994)

computer animation and sound - television ad for CTA, Victoria.
broadcast on Australian commercial stations, Spring 1994. (30 secs)
Made with IBM 286 laptop, PIP software, Roland Sound Canvas synth, voices of Lyn Gallacher and Berni Janssen. (script by Lyn Gallacher) in Composers' studio, St. Kilda, Channel 9 studios, Melbourne.
An ad for which I did all the computer graphics and music. A cute little minimalist piece of animated concrete poetry.

"A Sound Story for Phil Dadson" (1994)

slides and tape for transfer to video.
Media piece sent to Phil Dadson, June 1994 for his "Sound Stories" video series. (3 mins)
Made with 35 mm film, voice and synth recorded on cassette tape in composer's Studio, St. Kilda.
A story about my leaking roof which took 3 years to fix properly.

"Glebe Park" (1994)

B+W super-8 film.
For the 1994 White Gloves Film Festival (3 mins)
Made with Super 8 B+W film in Glebe Park, Canberra.
An environmental film - a reverie in Glebe Park in a Canberra winter. Starring a cheeky magpie-lark.

"Combinations" (1994)

Video Projection, Environmental Sounds on Tape, Koto, Khene, Live Electronics, Text, Performance Ritual.
Collaboration with Philip Blackburn, Leif Brush, Carolyn Erler, Miriam Gerberg, Mark Nowak.
Performed 4,5 November, Redeye Theatre, Minneapolis, MN. (38 mins)
The Video Component of this were environmental videotapes made by Leif Brush, as I remember. I also played some of 38:37 with the performance as well. This was a collage performance of many different elements, bringing together Minnesota artists whose work I admired.

"Two Solo Interactions" (1996)

for movement, computer graphics, computer music and speaking voice. Buchla Lightning, computer with Pip software, data projection.
Performed 22 June, 96, Canberra School of Art Gallery (10 minutes)
Made with IBM 286 laptop computer, PIP software, Roland Sound Canvas Synth, controlled by Buchla Lightning MIDI controller at Australian Centre for the Arts and Technology, Canberra.
Wearing infrared light emitting rings on my hands, I controlled both image and sound produced by the computer. In the second piece, in which fragments of words were displayed on the screen, I used that as a score for a live reading of a sound poem.

"Vacation 1 and 2" (1996-97)

environmental road videotapes, Western Victoria and New York State. Oct 96, Jan 97. (3 mins each)
Made with Video 8 technology on the road from Stawell to Melbourne, and on the road from Waterford, NY to Glens Falls, NY.
Structuralist videos. The Australian one looks out the front window of the car, the American one looks out the rear window.

"Elwood Evening Improvisations" (1997)

Live performance for videotape, Fairlight CVI, and Yamaha SU-10 sampler. Sept. 2-7, 97. (16 mins)
Made with Fairlight CVI, Yamaha SU-10 sampler, Video 8 camera at Warren Burt studio, Elwood.
Lights on the Elwood Canal are filmed at sunset with hundreds of mynahs screaming in the palm trees. This videotape is processed thru the CVI and the resonant filters on the Yamaha sampler. It's never been shown publically, because there seems to be no place to show it.

"Three Landscape Studies" (1997)

Videotape.
1) "Seven Watercolours" May '97 (32 mins);
2) Seventeen Autmnal Minutes in Landcox Park" May '97 (17 mins);
3) "Twenty One Views of a Wetlands Spring" Sept. '97 (6 mins)
Made with Video 8 technology in Mornington Peninsula, Landcox Park, East Brighton, Bittern Wetlands.
Structuralist environmental videotapes dealing with the importance of staring and meditation.

"Diversity" (1996-8)

Solo music theatre performance. Directed and choreographed by Sylvia Staehli.
Radio version prepared under the supervision of Andrew McLennan.
"An Extended Introduction" - extended vocal sounds, digital delay, effects unit, Lightning, video synthesis tape, text. Performed: 5 July 97, Budinsky's Theatre, Fitzroy. (13 mins)
"These Animals Are Not Metaphors" - videotape. (5 mins)
"A Simple Interaction 2" - Lightning, movement, synthesizer. Performed: Theatre of the Ordinary, Richmond, 18 July, 97. (5-7 mins)
"Movement Is Its Own Language" - videotape. (8 mins)
"An Illustrated Harangue" - sampler, portable loudspeaker in backpack, text, movement. Performed: 30 May 97, Theatre of the Ordinary, Richmond; 23 June 97, Budinsky's Theatre, Fitzroy. (5 mins)
"A Day at the Racists" - videotape. (5 mins)
"Loss" - pedestrian movement, newspaper prop, and interactive computer sound. (5 mins)
"64 Views of the Wetlands" - 64 Golden Chords" - videotape. (6 mins)
"Water/Texts" - texts, movement controlled sound processing, video backdrop, and environmental sounds. (15 mins).
First complete performance - 18-21 June 98, Dancehouse, Carlton (80 mins).
Video component made with: Fairlight CVI, Video 8 camera, Compel computer slideshow program, VHS video editing, Roland Sound Canvas synth. (1997-1998) at Warren Burt studio, Elwood. Shooting of Video 8 in Melbourne, Sydney, the Grampians, and Bittern Wetlands, 1996-97.
Diversity is a long political solo piece. Video sections alternate with live performance sections. All the kinds of image making I've done, from shaky amateur camera work to professionally made minimalist abstract images are included in it. (Article about this in Cantrill's Film Notes)

results.name: Sandpit Media Pty Ltd

roles_in_work.title: Ghosts, Toasts and the Things Unsaid

results.biography: Sandpit create interactive experiences for museums, brands and cultural institutions. Their work includes one-off custom digital interactives to complete organisational transformations. They have a passion for storytelling through design and technology.
